awd_titl_txt: Studies Relating to Black Hole Evaporation and to the Validity of the Semiclassical Approximation in Cosmology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports studies on black hole evaporation processes, with a focus on investigating quantum effects during and after the formation of a black hole.  The results may provide insight into the important question of what happens to the information about how a black hole forms.  Bose-Einstein condensates are systems that typically contain very cold atoms.  For certain configurations, quantum effects will occur which are in some important ways similar to those that occur for black holes.  Experimental studies of Bose-Einstein condensate analog black holes have been carried out.  Theoretical calculations will be made using the same techniques as are used to study quantum effects related to real black holes.  The results will be compared with the experimental data. The semiclassical approximation has been used to investigate quantum effects such as particle production in a variety of situations including the early universe.  It provides a bridge between macroscopic (classical) and microscopic (quantum) phenomena.  It's validity will be studied for an important model in which the universe is initially contracting, reaches a minimum size, and then begins to expand.  Particle production is expected to be particularly important during the contracting phase where it could significantly alter the dynamical evolution of the universe.  The results will help to determine whether the semiclassical approximation is valid in cases where quantum effects are significant.  Four graduate students, and probably some undergraduates, will participate in some aspects of the research, continuing a long history of their training in numerical and analytical research techniques and co-authorship on publications.  Results will be disseminated to the research community through publications and presentations at national and international meetings.  Some results obtained will be relevant for condensed matter physics.

The research supported by this grant addresses black hole evaporation, observable effects in Bose-Einstein condensates which can serve as black hole analogs, and early universe cosmology. Specifically, it will investigate questions related to the information about how a black hole forms, the correspondence between theoretical and experimental results related to quantum effects in analog black hole systems, and the validity of the semi-classical approximation in models of the universe.  In the case of black hole evaporation, the objectives include studying in detail quantum effects that occur if a spherically symmetric null shell collapses to form a black hole.  One goal is to check the accuracy of similar calculations in two dimensional dilaton theories of gravity.  It is also possible that insight will be gained into the question of what happens to the information about how the black hole formed.  Bose-Einstein condensates that can serve as analog black holes have been created in the laboratory.  The goal is to determine whether certain experimental results are in quantitative agreement with predictions resulting from quantum field theory in curved space calculations in the analog spacetime.  The primary goal for cosmology is to determine whether the semiclassical approximation is valid for models in which the universe contracts to a minimum size and then expands.  The models used will consist of a closed universe with a positive cosmological constant.  For the black hole evaporation project the stress-energy tensor for a quantized massless minimally coupled scalar field will be numerically computed in four-dimensions in the case of a null shell that collapses to form the black hole.  For the cosmology project the semiclassical backreaction equations will be solved numerically in the case that a massive conformally coupled scalar field is present.  The results will be used to investigate the validity of the semiclassical approximation in a collapsing universe.  The density density correlation function for a Bose-Einstein condensate analog black hole will be computed using quantum field theory in curved space techniques for a model that closely matches the velocity and sound speed profiles used in the experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research done for this grant addresses topics relating to quantum effects in black hole spacetimes, Bose-Einstein condensates that can serve as analogs for black holes, and cosmology.  These effects include both particle production and vacuum polarization.  The latter results in contributions to the energy density and pressure that can be nonzero even when no matter or radiation is present.

During the grant period a project was finished that involved studying some details of the particle production process that occurs when an object collapses to form a black hole.  It was shown in both two-dimensional and spherically symmetric four-dimensional spacetimes that the deviations in the spectrum of the produced particles from the late time behavior predicted by Hawking decrease much more slowly in time than would be expected by a naïve analysis.   

Also finished was the development of a method to compute the energy density and pressure of a certain type of quantized massless scalar field in a black hole that forms from the collapse of a spherical shell of pure energy such as light to form a black hole in four dimensions.  Work is in progress to implement that method. 

A quantity called the symmetric two-point function was computed in black hole spacetimes (and some other spacetimes) in two dimensions for a massless minimally coupled scalar field.  This function is related to correlations between the values the quantum field has at two different spacetime points.  A surprising result was that, if the points are fixed in space, this two-point function grows in time without bound for certain configurations or states of the field that can be used to describe black hole evaporation.  Evidence was later found that such growth may not occur for all black hole spacetimes in four dimensions or for all quantum fields.

Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) analog black can be studied in the laboratory.  Unlike real black holes, it is possible to observe effects inside their effective horizons since these are not true event horizons.  Certain effects of quantized sound waves were studied in some two-dimensional models.  It was shown that the distribution of the particles produced in the interior is very different than the distribution of particles predicted by Hawking for the exterior.  A second set of calculations involved a quantity that is related to correlations in the number densities of the atoms at two different locations.  This quantity was computed using three different models.  The results provided evidence that an approximation used by a different research group to compute this quantity using their experimental data may need to be improved.

It was shown that under a certain set of reasonable assumptions, the Universe would be expected to have had a time before inflation when its energy density and pressure were dominated by radiation rather than regular matter or some more exotic form of matter or energy.  It was found, using a simple model with a smooth transition between radiation domination and exponential expansion, that there could be measurable effects on the spectrum of the cosmic microwave background radiation.  Comparisons were made with prior calculations of this type, most of which had assumed a sudden transition between a radiation dominated and an exponentially expanding universe. 

One study involved investigating the effects of certain quantum fields a universe that begins with infinite size, contracts to a minimum size and then expands to an infinite size.  For a particular type of massive scalar field, it was found that if there is too much particle production, then the Universe collapses to zero size.  There is a technical problem in this type of calculation which involves the existence of solutions to the relevant equations that are not physically realistic.  A previous method to eliminate such solutions was adapted to this case, two new methods were developed and another method suggested by a different researcher was implemented.  All the methods gave similar results

If an electric field in a vacuum is strong enough then electrically charged particles are expected to be produced.  They will accelerate due to the force the electric field exerts on them and in the process create an electric field that is initially in the opposite direction and will partially cancel the original one.  The validity of an important approximation used in previous calculations, called the semiclassical approximation, was studied for simple models in two dimensions.  Evidence was found that the approximation is not valid in a very important case.

Six undergraduate students and six graduate students at Wake Forest University and one graduate student at the University of Valencia in Spain received training in various aspects of scientific research.  Six of the graduate students and one of the undergraduate students are currently coauthors on one or more of the publications relating to the projects mentioned above.
